questions.text: All of the following are essential features of ASD, except;
questions.solution:
Impairment of cognition is not an essential feature of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Cognitive abilities in individuals with ASD can vary widely, ranging from intellectual disability to average or above-average intelligence. While some individuals with ASD may have cognitive impairments, it is not a universal feature of the disorder.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

B.Stereotyped and restricted behaviour

Stereotyped and restricted behaviour is a hallmark feature of ASD. These include repetitive motor movements, insistence on sameness, and highly restricted interests, which are commonly observed in individuals with ASD.

C.Difficulty in getting socializing

Difficulty in socializing is a key characteristic of ASD. This includes deficits in social-emotional reciprocity, nonverbal communication, and challenges in developing and maintaining relationships.

D.Persistent deficits in communication

Persistent deficits in communication are another core feature of ASD. This includes difficulties in verbal and nonverbal communication, affecting interactions with others.

Key Takeaways:

  • ASD involves persistent deficits in social communication and interaction and restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour.
  • Cognitive impairment is not a universal feature of ASD and can vary widely among individuals.
  • Difficulty in socializing and deficits in communication are key components of ASD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Beck's cognitive triad of depression?
questions.solution:
Introjection is not a component of Beck's cognitive triad of depression. Introjection refers to the unconscious adoption of the ideas or attitudes of others, often associated with psychoanalytic theories, but it is not part of Beck's cognitive model of depression.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

  • A. Automatic thoughts
    Automatic thoughts     are an essential aspect of Beck's cognitive model. These are the involuntary, negative thoughts that depressed individuals experience, which reinforce their negative view of themselves, the world, and the future. These thoughts contribute to the cognitive distortions associated with depression.
  • C. Cognitive distortions
    Cognitive distortions     are a key part of Beck's theory, referring to irrational thought patterns that individuals with depression tend to exhibit, such as overgeneralization, catastrophizing, and black-and-white thinking. These distortions lead to and maintain negative thinking patterns within the cognitive triad.
  • D. Dysfunctional beliefs
    Dysfunctional beliefs     refer to the deeper, often unconscious beliefs about the self, the world, and the future that contribute to the cognitive triad. These beliefs support and are part of the negative thinking patterns characteristic of depression.

    • Key Takeaways:

    • Beck's cognitive triad involves the negative view of the self, the world, and the future, which together contribute to the development and maintenance of depression.
    • Introjection is not part of Beck's cognitive triad but is related to psychoanalytic concepts of internalizing others' views.
    • Cognitive distortions and automatic thoughts are central to Beck's model and contribute to the negative cognitive patterns seen in depression.

questions.text: As per "WHO Mental health gap action plan", which of the following is not a priority condition?
questions.solution:
Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not listed as a priority condition in the WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP). While OCD is a significant mental health condition, it is not one of the conditions the WHO has specifically prioritized in its global action plan for mental health.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

  • A. Depression
    Depression     is a major mental health condition and is one of the key priorities in the mhGAP. It is a leading cause of disability worldwide, and addressing depression is central to improving global mental health.
  • B. Psychotic conditions including schizophrenia
    Psychotic conditions, including schizophrenia    , are also prioritized in the mhGAP. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders require urgent attention and intervention, as they often lead to long-term disability without treatment.
  • D. Children with mental illnesses
    Mental disorders in children     and adolescents are included in the mhGAP's priority conditions. These encompass developmental and behavioral disorders, and addressing them early is crucial for improving mental health outcomes in later life.

    • Key Takeaways:

    • The WHO Mental Health Gap Action Programme (mhGAP) prioritizes conditions such as depression, psychotic conditions, epilepsy, suicide, dementia, substance use disorders, and mental health issues in children and adolescents.
    • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), though important, is not specifically listed as a priority condition in the mhGAP.
    • Early intervention for conditions like depression, psychosis, and children's mental illnesses is key to improving overall global mental health outcomes.

choices.text: Patient with severe chronic diseases and ego dystonic condition
Acute psychiatric illness along with crisis in a patient
Cognitive decline and physical symptoms in a person
Person with good motivation & who can control his frustration

questions.text: In which of the following condition, supportive psychotherapy is not needed?
questions.solution:
A person with good motivation and the ability to control their frustration does not need supportive psychotherapy. Supportive psychotherapy is typically indicated for individuals experiencing significant distress, dysfunction, or those who are unable to cope effectively with their circumstances. A person who is able to manage their emotions and frustration likely has sufficient coping mechanisms and resilience, and thus does not require extensive supportive therapy.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

  • A. Patient with severe chronic diseases and ego dystonic condition
    Supportive psychotherapy is often needed for patients with severe chronic diseases and those with ego-dystonic conditions (where the individual experiences distress from behaviors or thoughts that are inconsistent with their self-image). These individuals may struggle to cope with their conditions, and psychotherapy can provide emotional support and help them develop better coping strategies.
  • B. Acute psychiatric illness along with crisis in a patient
    Acute psychiatric illnesses     often involve significant emotional distress, and when combined with a crisis, they typically require supportive psychotherapy. This therapy helps the patient navigate through their immediate emotional turmoil, stabilizing their mental state and providing strategies to manage the crisis effectively.
  • C. Cognitive decline and physical symptoms in a person
    Individuals experiencing cognitive decline or physical symptoms due to a medical condition often require supportive psychotherapy. These patients may face challenges in coping with their cognitive or physical changes, and psychotherapy can provide emotional support, help them adjust to new realities, and manage any distress associated with their symptoms.

    • Key Takeaways:

    • Supportive psychotherapy is most beneficial for patients experiencing distress, emotional turmoil, or difficulties in coping with chronic illness, psychiatric crises, or cognitive decline.
    • A person with good motivation and the ability to manage frustration likely has adequate coping mechanisms and would not typically require supportive psychotherapy.
    • Supportive psychotherapy is aimed at helping individuals manage their emotions and improve their coping strategies during challenging times.

    Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6486211/

questions.text: Which of the following is less associated with korsakoff's psychosis?
questions.solution:
Ophthalmoplegia is less associated with Korsakoff's psychosis. Korsakoff syndrome, which is typically caused by a thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, is characterized by memory problems, confabulation, and other cognitive deficits, but ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities) is not a typical feature of the disorder. Ophthalmoplegia is more commonly seen in Wernicke's encephalopathy, the acute phase of thiamine deficiency that often precedes Korsakoff syndrome. Therefore, ophthalmoplegia is not considered a core symptom of Korsakoff's psychosis.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

A.Memory problem
Memory problems are a hallmark feature of Korsakoff's psychosis. Patients often experience anterograde amnesia(inability to form new memories) and retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). These memory deficits are significant and central to the diagnosis of Korsakoff syndrome.

B. Confabulation
Confabulation (the production of false memories without the intention to deceive) is another key feature of Korsakoff's psychosis. This occurs as a result of the memory impairment, where individuals unconsciously fill in gaps in their memory with fabricated details.

D. Peripheral neuropathy
Peripheral neuropathy, often presenting as tingling or numbness in the limbs, is commonly associated with thiamine deficiency and can be seen in individuals with alcohol misuse, which is often the underlying cause of Korsakoff's syndrome. It is a frequent co-occurrence and can contribute to the patient's clinical presentation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Korsakoff's psychosis is primarily characterized by memory problems and confabulation.
  • Ophthalmoplegia is more characteristic of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is the acute phase of thiamine deficiency and typically precedes Korsakoff syndrome.
  • Peripheral neuropathy can occur due to thiamine deficiency and is often seen in individuals with alcohol misuse.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430729/

questions.text: We use cannabinoids in all of the given conditions except;
questions.solution:
Rett's syndrome is the condition where cannabinoids are not typically used. While cannabinoids, especially cannabidiol (CBD), have demonstrated therapeutic benefits in conditions like Tuberous Sclerosis, Dravet syndrome, and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome for managing seizures, there is limited evidence supporting the use of cannabinoids in Rett's syndrome. Rett's syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder primarily affecting girls, leading to a loss of motor skills and speech. Currently, cannabinoids are not a first-line treatment for this condition.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

A.Tuberous Sclerosis

Cannabinoids, particularly CBD, can help manage seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis. This genetic disorder can cause tumors in multiple organs and is often linked with epilepsy, for which cannabinoids have been shown to be beneficial.

B.Dravet syndrome

Cannabinoids, particularly CBD, have been approved for treating seizures in Dravet syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy that is resistant to many traditional treatments. CBD has shown significant efficacy in reducing seizure frequency and severity.

C.Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

Cannabinoids, especially CBD, are also used in the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. This condition is characterized by frequent, diverse seizures, and cannabinoids have shown promise in helping to control them.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cannabinoids are used for managing seizures in conditions like Tuberous Sclerosis, Dravet syndrome, and Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Rett's syndrome does not currently have evidence supporting the use of cannabinoids as a treatment for its symptoms.
  • CBD is the primary cannabinoid used for seizure management in these conditions.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5716495/

questions.text: Following EEG wave is seen in which phase of sleep cycle?
questions.solution:
During REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep, the EEG shows a pattern of activity that is very similar to wakefulness, with low-amplitude, high-frequency waves. The brain is highly active during REM sleep, which is also characterized by rapid eye movements under closed eyelids.

Other options:

In contrast, the other stages of sleep are characterized by different EEG patterns:

NREM I (stage 1): Theta waves and some alpha waves

NREM II (stage 2): Sleep spindles and K-complexes interrupt theta waves

NREM III (slow wave sleep): High-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves

So the EEG pattern most resembling wakefulness, with low-amplitude, high-frequency waves, is seen specifically during REM sleep.

Key Takeaways:

  • REM sleep is characterized by a distinct EEG pattern resembling wakefulness, with low-amplitude, high-frequency waves.
  • NREM I has a pattern of theta waves, while NREM II is associated with sleep spindles and K-complexes.
  • NREM III shows high-amplitude, low-frequency delta waves, indicative of deep, restorative sleep.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK10996/

choices.text: Can be triggered by antidepressant therapy
Can be more than 4 episodes of bipolar in a year

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Rapid Cycling?
questions.solution:
Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is actually more common in females than in males. Studies show that approximately 72% of cases of rapid cycling occur in women, making it significantly more prevalent in females.

Incorrect Option Explanations:

A. Can be associated with hypothyroidism
There is a known connection between hypothyroidism and bipolar disorder, particularly in individuals with rapid cycling. Thyroid dysfunction can influence mood regulation and contribute to the occurrence of rapid cycling.

B. Can be triggered by antidepressant therapy
Antidepressant therapy has the potential to induce rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder. This is especially true when antidepressants are used without adequate mood stabilizers.

C.Can be more than 4 episodes of bipolar in a year
Rapid cycling is specifically defined as having four or more mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a 12-month period. Therefore, this is a hallmark feature of rapid cycling.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rapid cycling is more common in females rather than males.
  • It can be associated with hypothyroidism, and antidepressants may trigger rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.
  • Rapid cycling is defined by having four or more episodes of mood changes within a year.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9766777/
